awd_titl_txt: Transducing Thermal and Optical Energies to Motion and Electricity with Coherent-Domain Ferroelastic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

"Transducing Thermal and Optical Energies to Motion and Electricity with Coherent-Domain Ferroelastic Materials" by Junqiao Wu, University of California-Berkeley

Research Objectives and Approaches

The objective of this program is to demonstrate a transformative technology with superior performance to transduce thermal and optical energies to mechanical motion and electricity. A training program will also be built for undergraduate and community college students through curriculum and research developments.
The approach is to exploit the large spontaneous strain arising from the ferroelastic phase transition of VO2-based single-crystal microbeams. This beam is mechanically coupled with a passive clamping beam or a piezoelectric layer, forming a composite beam that bends in a tunable temperature range over which the active material undergoes the phase transition. 

Intellectual Merit

The proposed research seeks to transform conventional thermal-optical-mechanical-electrical energy transducing technologies using innovative material systems coupling multiple functionalities with coherent domain structures. Low-grade waste heat from sources slightly above room temperature is extremely abundant. In this temperature regime (<100 Celsius), conventional technologies such as thermoelectrics become too inefficient to be practical. The proposed innovative approach is able to convert low-grade waste heat into mechanical motion and electricity at efficiencies potentially much higher than conventional technologies. 

Broader Impacts

On the global energy diagram, more than 80% of the power is generated through thermal processes, and more than 50% of the total energy produced is lost as heat. The proposed research benefits society by enabling novel, microscale thermal actuation and waste heat recovery technologies at unprecedentedly high performance and low cost. The proposed project will broaden its impact by developing a "Materials for Energy" training program at Berkeley.

por.por_cntn:
The research objective of this project is to demonstrate transformative technologies to transduce thermal and optical energies to mechanical motion and electricity using ferroelastic materials. In this project, we

1. Successfully synthesized undoped, doped and graded doped oxide single cyrstal oxide nanowires, providing an ideal platform for investigation and exploit of domain effects in their phase transition. 

2. Demonstrated high-efficiency, high-emplitude, high-force and high-speed actuation based on single oxide nanowires, laying a foundation for areas where microactuation is needed with these high performance metrics, such as robotics, microfluidics and biology. 

3. Decoupled the structural and electronic phase transitions in vanadium oxide, pointing out a strong evidence that the metal-insulator transition is electron-electron correlation driven, and not fundamentally related to the structural transition. This sheds light onto the transition mechanism which has been debated in the field for over 50 years.

4. Working with our collaborators, demonstrated that the thermal conductivity of a semiconductor alloy can be suppressed below the random alloy limit, promising application for areas such as thermoelectrics and thermal barrier coating. 

5. Filed a patent based on our developed powerful microscale actuators that simultaneously achieve high amplitude, highwork output, and high speed.

In addition, our work broadly impacted our home institution: 

6. Our work in this peoject has helped the Electronic Materials Program in the nearby Lawrence Berkeley NationalLaboratory (where the PI holds joint position) to gain equipment funding from DOE to set up a new pulsed laserdeposition system (~ $400K), for deposition of a wide range of oxide thin films, which also in turn benefits this project.

7.  Our results in this project have also allowed us to compete and win a grant from industry (Samsung Inc), with which we purchased a new cryostat for thermal characterization at variable temperatures, which also enhances the research infrastructure in our home institution. 

On the outreach and knowledge dissemination side, 

8. Our work has offered training opportunities for postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduate students, and prepared them for a research or development future career.

9. The research results were published in high-profile peer-review journals and presented in international conferences, which are disseminated to the research community in a timely way.

10. During open house days such as the annual Cal Day (the campus open house day), visiting days for local highschoolers, and visiting days for international scholars, our lab is open and the research activities are exposed and explained to visitors. We also collaborated with the university and museum to host visitor programs.

In summary, our work has produced outcomes that accomplished our objectives, and broadly impacted the communities far beyond the principle field.
